P.title: Will SpaceX's Starship enable the commercialization of space travel by 2025?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, SpaceX has officially begun commercial operations of its Starship spacecraft for the purpose of space travel accessible to non-governmental, paying customers. Commercialization is defined as offering and conducting paid space travel services to individuals or private entities beyond governmental or scientific missions. The service must be operational, with at least one commercial flight completed. Confirmation must come from an official SpaceX announcement or credible media reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post). In the event of a partial service offering (e.g., limited to specific routes or types of customers), the question will resolve as Yes if the service is intended for broader public availability. Temporary or promotional one-off flights do not count towards this question's resolution.

Q_given_P.title: Given SpaceX's Starship enables the commercialization of space travel by 2025, will SpaceX establish a permanent human settlement on Mars before 2040?
Q_given_P.body:
This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2040, SpaceX has established a permanent human settlement on Mars. A "permanent human settlement" is defined as a self-sustaining habitat capable of supporting human life indefinitely without requiring constant resupply from Earth. The settlement must include living quarters, life support systems, and facilities for at least 10 people. The establishment of the settlement must be confirmed by SpaceX through an official announcement or documentation. In the absence of a public announcement, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post) are sufficient. The settlement must be operational, not in a trial phase. Temporary habitats or research stations do not count towards this question's resolution.

P.title: Will North Korea engage in a significant diplomatic negotiation with a Western country by 2025?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, North Korea has engaged in significant diplomatic negotiations with at least one Western country. Significant diplomatic negotiations are defined as official talks directly involving North Korean and Western country representatives, aimed at addressing major policy issues, security concerns, or normalization of relations. The negotiations must be officially acknowledged by both participating parties or confirmed through a joint statement. In the absence of official acknowledgment, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post, Reuters) are sufficient for resolution. The term "Western country" refers to any country in North America, Western Europe, or Australasia. Preliminary talks, unofficial dialogues, or negotiations solely through intermediaries do not count towards this question's resolution.

Q_given_P.title: Given North Korea engages in significant diplomatic negotiations with a Western country by 2025, will it significantly reform its legal system by 2030?
Q_given_P.body:
This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, North Korea has implemented significant reforms in its legal system. Significant reforms are defined as changes that lead to increased transparency, the establishment of independent judiciary bodies, the introduction of laws that significantly enhance human rights protections, or the reduction of the government's direct control over legal proceedings. The reforms must be recognized and reported by at least three reputable international news organizations (BBC, The New York Times, The Guardian, Reuters) or international human rights organizations (Amnesty International, Human Rights Watch). In the absence of direct reports, official government announcements or documentation will be considered. The question will resolve as No if such reforms are not implemented or if they are reversed before the resolution date. In the case of ambiguous reforms, a consensus among the aforementioned sources will be required to determine the significance of the reforms.

P.title: Will a new AI-driven epidemiology tool predict the next global pandemic with over 90% accuracy before 2030?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2030, a new AI-driven epidemiology tool is developed and successfully predicts the next global pandemic with over 90% accuracy. The prediction must be specific to the pathogen type (e.g., virus, bacteria), its origin, and the timeframe of outbreak. The tool's prediction accuracy must be verified by a consensus of at least three leading health organizations (e.g., WHO, CDC, ECDC) or by publication in at least three peer-reviewed scientific journals. The tool must be publicly acknowledged by these organizations or publications as having met the 90% accuracy threshold in its prediction. In the event of multiple tools meeting these criteria, the resolution will be based on the first tool to be publicly acknowledged as meeting the accuracy threshold. Predictions made retrospectively, after the pandemic has begun, do not count towards this question's resolution.

Q_given_P.title: Conditional on a new AI-driven epidemiology tool predicting the next global pandemic with over 90% accuracy before 2030, will the widespread adoption of COVID-19 vaccines lead to a permanent change in workplace dynamics by 2030?
Q_given_P.body:

The prediction must be specific to the pathogen type (e.g., virus, bacteria), its origin, and the timeframe of outbreak. The tool must be publicly acknowledged by these organizations or publications as having met the 90% accuracy threshold in its prediction. In the event of multiple tools meeting these criteria, the resolution will be based on the first tool to be publicly acknowledged as meeting the accuracy threshold. Predictions made retrospectively, after the pandemic has begun, do not count towards this question's resolution.

Then, will the widespread adoption of COVID-19 vaccines lead to a permanent change in workplace dynamics by 2030? This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, there is a significant and permanent change in workplace dynamics directly attributable to the widespread adoption of COVID-19 vaccines. Significant change is defined as:
- A permanent increase of at least 20% in the number of employees working remotely or in hybrid models compared to pre-pandemic levels (2019).
- The implementation of permanent flexible working hours by at least 50% of Fortune 500 companies.
- The establishment of permanent health and safety protocols in the workplace, including but not limited to vaccination requirements, that were not standard prior to the pandemic.

Changes must be documented by credible sources, including but not limited to surveys by major human resources consultancies (e.g., Deloitte, PwC), reports from reputable news organizations (BBC, The New York Times, The Guardian), or official statements from companies. Temporary measures or changes solely due to government mandates that are lifted do not count towards this question's resolution.

P.title: Will a significant discovery in particle physics be made through computational methods by 2030?
P.body:
This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, a significant discovery in particle physics is made through computational methods. A "significant discovery" is defined as a discovery that leads to a substantial revision of the Standard Model of particle physics, or provides empirical evidence for phenomena not predicted by the Standard Model, such as supersymmetry, extra dimensions, or dark matter interactions.

The discovery must be confirmed through publication in a peer-reviewed scientific journal of high impact (e.g., Nature, Science, Physical Review Letters) and must be recognized by a leading scientific organization in the field of particle physics (e.g., CERN, Fermilab, International Particle Physics Outreach Group).

Computational methods include, but are not limited to, simulations, data analysis algorithms, and machine learning techniques. The use of computational methods must be central to the discovery, not merely supplementary.

In the event of multiple discoveries, the question will resolve as Yes if at least one meets the above criteria.

In the absence of direct evidence linking the breakthrough to string theory, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post) are sufficient. The breakthrough must represent a substantial improvement over current capabilities and not merely an incremental advancement.

P.title: Will France implement a nationwide carbon-neutral initiative by 2030?
P.body:
This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, France has officially implemented a nationwide initiative that is recognized as carbon-neutral. The initiative must encompass actions across multiple sectors, including but not limited to energy, transportation, industry, and agriculture, aimed at achieving a net-zero carbon footprint for the country.

The initiative must be confirmed by an official government announcement or documentation. In the absence of a public announcement, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post) are sufficient.

For the purpose of this question, "carbon-neutral" means that any carbon emissions produced by France are balanced by an equivalent amount of carbon sequestration or offsetting measures, within the same calendar year. The verification of carbon neutrality must be conducted by an independent, internationally recognized environmental organization.

In the event of partial implementation (e.g., limited to specific regions or sectors), the question will resolve as Yes only if there is a clear, government-confirmed plan for nationwide coverage by the end of 2030.

A "major shift" in global climate policy is defined as the adoption of new, substantial climate policies or amendments to existing policies by at least three of the following entities: the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC), the European Union, the United States, China, and India. These policies must represent a significant departure from current strategies and aim to substantially reduce greenhouse gas emissions or enhance climate resilience. The shift must be confirmed by official documentation from the relevant entities or credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post, Reuters).

In the event of partial implementation (e.g., limited to specific regions or sectors), the question will resolve as Yes only if there is a clear, government-confirmed plan for nationwide coverage by the end of 2030.

If the condition is not met, resolves N/A.

In the event of a dispute over leadership, the consensus among these sources will be considered definitive.

reasons: Climate change can potentially influence the emergence and spread of infectious diseases. For example, rising temperatures can expand the habitats of disease vectors like mosquitoes, which can lead to the spread of diseases such as malaria and dengue fever.

Changes in climate can also affect human behavior and migration patterns, which can influence the spread of infectious diseases. For instance, extreme weather events and changing agricultural conditions can lead to displacement and overcrowding, creating conditions conducive to the spread of infectious diseases.
The combination of these questions could be of interest to public health officials, policymakers, and researchers who are studying the interconnected impacts of climate change and public health.

P.title: Will a significant international climate change treaty be ratified by 2030?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, a significant international climate change treaty is ratified. A "significant" treaty is defined as one that includes commitments from at least 75% of the world's nations and aims to reduce global greenhouse gas emissions by at least 40% from 1990 levels by 2050. The treaty must be ratified by the participating countries' governments or relevant governing bodies. Ratification is confirmed through official government announcements or documentation. In the absence of a public announcement, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post) are sufficient. The treaty must be new, not an amendment or extension of an existing treaty. In the event of multiple treaties, the question resolves as Yes if at least one meets these criteria.

P.title: Will robotics achieve a major breakthrough in autonomous vehicle technology by 2025?
P.body:
This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, a major breakthrough in autonomous vehicle technology is achieved, defined as:

- The development and successful public demonstration of an autonomous vehicle capable of navigating complex urban environments without human intervention, with a success rate of at least 95%.
- The breakthrough must be recognized by a leading industry body or consortium in the field of robotics or autonomous vehicles, such as the Association for Advancing Automation (A3) or the International Federation of Robotics (IFR).

The breakthrough must be documented in at least two reputable technology or science news outlets (e.g., Wired, TechCrunch, Science Daily) or in peer-reviewed scientific journals. 

In the event of multiple claims of breakthroughs, the resolution will be based on the first documented instance meeting the above criteria. 

Developments that only incrementally improve existing technologies without demonstrating a significant leap in capabilities will not be considered a major breakthrough for the purpose of this question.

P.title: Will a breakthrough in nuclear fusion technology be achieved by 2030?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, a breakthrough in nuclear fusion technology is achieved and publicly announced. A "breakthrough" is defined as achieving a net energy gain from a nuclear fusion reaction that is sustainable and reproducible in a controlled environment. The breakthrough must be recognized and confirmed by at least one of the following: the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA), the Department of Energy (DOE) of the United States, or a similar authoritative body in the field of nuclear energy. Additionally, the achievement must be documented in a peer-reviewed scientific journal or presented at a major scientific conference. In the absence of an official announcement, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post, Reuters) are sufficient. The question will resolve as No if these conditions are not met by the specified date.

Q_given_P.title: Given a breakthrough in nuclear fusion technology by 2030, will the United States become the world's largest producer of renewable energy by 2030?

This will resolve as Yes if the United States is officially recognized as the world's largest producer of renewable energy, measured by total megawatts (MW) of renewable energy capacity installed or by total renewable energy generated in a year. Renewable energy includes solar, wind, hydroelectric, geothermal, and biomass energy sources. The assessment will be based on data and reports from authoritative sources such as the International Energy Agency (IEA), the U.S. Energy Information Administration (EIA), or equivalent. In the event of discrepancies between sources, the source with the most comprehensive and recent data will be considered authoritative. The resolution will consider only operational capacity, excluding projects under construction or in planning stages. In case of a tie or near-tie (within a 1% margin), the question will resolve as No, requiring clear leadership in renewable energy production.

P.title: Will a major technology company face a landmark ethics investigation by the United States government before 2025?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2025, a major technology company (defined as a company with a market capitalization exceeding $100 billion USD at the time of the investigation's announcement) faces a landmark ethics investigation by the United States government. A "landmark ethics investigation" is defined as an investigation that is publicly announced by a U.S. federal government agency, such as the Federal Trade Commission (FTC), the Department of Justice (DOJ), or the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC), and involves allegations of significant ethical breaches that could potentially lead to regulatory changes, substantial fines, or major shifts in company policy. The investigation must be new and not a continuation or expansion of previously known issues. Confirmation of such an investigation must come from official government releases or credible news reports from reputable sources such as The New York Times, The Washington Post, Reuters, or Bloomberg. In the event of ambiguous situations, the resolution will default to a No unless clear evidence is presented.

P.title: Will the widespread adoption of COVID-19 vaccines lead to a permanent change in workplace dynamics by 2030?
P.body:
This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, there is a significant and permanent change in workplace dynamics directly attributable to the widespread adoption of COVID-19 vaccines. Significant change is defined as:
- A permanent increase of at least 20% in the number of employees working remotely or in hybrid models compared to pre-pandemic levels (2019).
- The implementation of permanent flexible working hours by at least 50% of Fortune 500 companies.
- The establishment of permanent health and safety protocols in the workplace, including but not limited to vaccination requirements, that were not standard prior to the pandemic.

Changes must be documented by credible sources, including but not limited to surveys by major human resources consultancies (e.g., Deloitte, PwC), reports from reputable news organizations (BBC, The New York Times, The Guardian), or official statements from companies. Temporary measures or changes solely due to government mandates that are lifted do not count towards this question's resolution.

A "major infectious disease outbreak" is defined as an event where a disease causes significant morbidity or mortality in at least three countries across different WHO regions, and is officially declared a Public Health Emergency of International Concern (PHEIC) by the World Health Organization (WHO).

New global health policies must be adopted by at least five member countries of the United Nations and aim to address the prevention, preparedness, or response to infectious diseases. These policies must be documented in official government publications or announcements. In the absence of such documentation, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post) will be considered sufficient evidence.

In the event that multiple outbreaks occur, the question will resolve as Yes if any one of them meets the criteria above.

P.title: Will France see a major electoral reform as a result of a significant social movement before 2030?

P.title: Will a major epidemic influence the outcome of a national election in any country before 2030?

The influence on the election outcome must be clearly attributable to the epidemic, such as through a significant shift in public opinion, voter turnout, or the implementation of election-related policies (e.g., mail-in voting, election postponement). P.title: Will the United States become the world's largest producer of renewable energy by 2030?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, the United States is officially recognized as the world's largest producer of renewable energy, measured by total megawatts (MW) of renewable energy capacity installed or by total renewable energy generated in a year. Renewable energy includes solar, wind, hydroelectric, geothermal, and biomass energy sources. The assessment will be based on data and reports from authoritative sources such as the International Energy Agency (IEA), the U.S. Energy Information Administration (EIA), or equivalent. In the event of discrepancies between sources, the source with the most comprehensive and recent data will be considered authoritative. The resolution will consider only operational capacity, excluding projects under construction or in planning stages. In case of a tie or near-tie (within a 1% margin), the question will resolve as No, requiring clear leadership in renewable energy production.

P.title: Will a new infectious disease be identified that significantly impacts global health by 2025?

Q_given_P.title: Given a new infectious disease significantly impacts global health by 2025, will the United Kingdom launch a new national health initiative to combat future pandemics by 2025?
Q_given_P.body:
This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, a new infectious disease is identified that significantly impacts global health. Significant impact is defined as:
- The disease causing at least 1,000 confirmed deaths worldwide;
- The disease leading to the declaration of a Public Health Emergency of International Concern (PHEIC) by the World Health Organization (WHO);
- The disease resulting in widespread travel restrictions or lockdowns in at least three countries.

The identification of the disease must be confirmed by the WHO or a similar authoritative health organization. In the absence of an official announcement, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post) are sufficient.

In the event that multiple diseases meet these criteria, the question will resolve as Yes if any one of them does so before the specified date. Diseases that are mutations or variants of previously identified diseases do not count unless they are classified as distinct new diseases by the WHO.

Resolution criteria for the outcome: Resolves YES if, by December 31, 2025, the United Kingdom has officially launched a new national health initiative aimed at combating future pandemics. The initiative must be comprehensive, addressing at least prevention, detection, and response strategies for future pandemics. It must be officially announced by the UK government or a relevant health authority. In the absence of a public announcement, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post) are sufficient. The initiative must be new, not an extension or rebranding of existing programs. In the event of a partial launch (e.g., limited to specific regions or aspects of pandemic preparedness), the question will resolve as Yes if the initiative is intended for nationwide application.
If the condition is not met, resolves N/A.

- The disease resulting in widespread travel restrictions or lockdowns in at least three countries.

In the event that multiple diseases meet these criteria, the question will resolve as Yes if any one of them does so before the specified date. Diseases that are mutations or variants of previously identified diseases do not count unless they are classified as distinct new diseases by the WHO.

2. The United Kingdom officially launches a new national health initiative aimed at combating future pandemics. The initiative must be new, not an extension or rebranding of existing programs. In the event of a partial launch (e.g., limited to specific regions or aspects of pandemic preparedness), the question will resolve as Yes if the initiative is intended for nationwide application.

P.title: Will the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention publish a comprehensive report on the health impacts of climate change by 2025?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) has published a comprehensive report on the health impacts of climate change. The report must cover a wide range of health impacts directly and indirectly related to climate change, including but not limited to: - Changes in the distribution and prevalence of vector-borne diseases; - Impacts on mental health and well-being; - Effects on air quality and respiratory health; - The influence of extreme weather events on public health. The report must be publicly accessible and recognized by the CDC as comprehensive in its coverage of climate change's health impacts. In the absence of a single comprehensive report, a series of publications by the CDC that collectively cover the criteria above will also satisfy the resolution criteria. The resolution will rely on official CDC announcements or publications. In the event that the CDC has not published such a report by the specified date, the question will resolve as No.

The report must be publicly accessible and recognized by the CDC as comprehensive in its coverage of climate change's health impacts. In the absence of a single comprehensive report, a series of publications by the CDC that collectively cover the criteria above will also satisfy the resolution criteria. The resolution will rely on official CDC announcements or publications. In the event that the CDC has not published such a report by the specified date, the question will resolve as No. (2) There are significant and lasting changes in public health policy in the United States that can be directly attributed to the outcome of the 2020 US presidential election. Significant changes include, but are not limited to, reforms in healthcare access, pandemic preparedness, mental health services, and environmental health policies. The changes must be enacted into law or official policy and must have been implemented with evidence of impact. Attribution to the 2020 election outcome must be confirmed through official statements, legislative records, or analysis by at least three reputable news sources (e.g., BBC, The New York Times, The Washington Post). In the absence of direct attribution, a consensus among at least three health policy experts featured in major publications may also suffice. Temporary measures or policies that are reversed before the resolution date do not count towards this question's resolution.

P.title: Will India implement a nationwide policy to significantly reduce air pollution levels by 2025?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, India has officially implemented a nationwide policy aimed at significantly reducing air pollution levels. The policy must demonstrate a clear, measurable goal for reduction in major pollutants (e.g., PM2.5, PM10, NOx, SO2) compared to 2020 levels. Significant reduction is defined as a decrease of at least 20% in the annual average concentration of these pollutants across major cities in India. The implementation of the policy must be confirmed by an official government announcement or documentation. In the absence of a public announcement, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post) are sufficient. The policy must be in effect, not merely proposed or in a planning stage. In the event of regional policies that collectively cover the entire nation, the question will resolve as Yes if these policies meet the overall reduction goal.

P.title: Will California implement a state-backed cryptocurrency by 2025?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, the state of California has officially implemented a state-backed cryptocurrency. The cryptocurrency must be recognized and regulated by an official state authority, such as the California Department of Financial Protection and Innovation, and must be designed for use as a legal tender within the state. Implementation is defined as the cryptocurrency being publicly available for use in transactions and recognized by the state for tax payments or other governmental fees. Confirmation of implementation must come from an official government announcement or documentation. In the absence of a public announcement, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post) are sufficient. The cryptocurrency must be operational, not in a trial phase. In the event of a partial implementation (e.g., limited to specific sectors or regions), the question will resolve as Yes if the cryptocurrency is intended for statewide use.

Discoveries that only lead to minor adjustments or are limited to national or regional significance do not meet this criterion. The resolution will consider only those changes that are implemented and publicly acknowledged by the respective governments or organizations by the resolution date.

P.title: Will a new infectious disease emerge with a global infection rate exceeding 1% before 2030?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2030, a new infectious disease emerges with a global infection rate exceeding 1% of the world's population. The infection rate must be confirmed by the World Health Organization (WHO) or the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). For the purpose of this question, a "new infectious disease" refers to a pathogen not previously identified in humans before the date of this question. The global infection rate is defined as the percentage of the world's population confirmed to be infected by the disease, as reported by the WHO or CDC. In the absence of direct reports from these organizations, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post, Reuters) will be considered sufficient. In the event of conflicting reports, the average of the reported rates from these sources will be used to determine the resolution. This question does not consider the severity of the disease or the death rate, focusing solely on the infection rate.

P.title: Will a major ethical controversy in medical research lead to global policy changes in health care by 2030?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, a major ethical controversy in medical research leads to the implementation of new global health care policies or significant amendments to existing ones. A "major ethical controversy" is defined as an event or series of events in medical research that raises significant ethical concerns, receives widespread coverage in at least five reputable international news outlets (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post, Reuters), and prompts a response from international health organizations (e.g., World Health Organization) or coalitions of nations. The new or amended policies must be aimed at addressing the ethical concerns raised and must be adopted by at least 50% of the member states of the World Health Organization. The resolution will consider only policies that have been officially announced and documented by the relevant governing bodies. In the event of multiple controversies, the question will resolve as Yes if any one of them meets these criteria.

P_and_Q.title: Will both a major ethical controversy in medical research lead to global policy changes in health care and a new infectious disease emerge by 2030 that leads to a global pandemic with a mortality rate exceeding that of COVID-19?
P_and_Q.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, both of the following occur: (a) A major ethical controversy in medical research leads to the implementation of new global health care policies or significant amendments to existing ones. A "major ethical controversy" is defined as an event or series of events in medical research that raises significant ethical concerns, receives widespread coverage in at least five reputable international news outlets (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post, Reuters), and prompts a response from international health organizations (e.g., World Health Organization) or coalitions of nations. The new or amended policies must be aimed at addressing the ethical concerns raised and must be adopted by at least 50% of the member states of the World Health Organization. The resolution will consider only policies that have been officially announced and documented by the relevant governing bodies. In the event of multiple controversies, the question will resolve as Yes if any one of them meets these criteria. (b) A new infectious disease emerges that leads to a global pandemic with a mortality rate exceeding that of COVID-19 as reported by the World Health Organization (WHO). The mortality rate is defined as the number of confirmed deaths divided by the number of confirmed cases. For the purpose of this question, "global pandemic" is defined as an outbreak of a disease that occurs over a wide geographic area and affects an exceptionally high proportion of the global population. The emergence of the disease must be confirmed by the WHO, and its global impact must be reported by at least three reputable news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post). In the event that the WHO is dissolved or rendered inactive, a consensus of at least three leading health organizations (e.g., CDC, ECDC, China CDC) will be required for resolution. The question will resolve as No if no such disease emerges by the specified date.

P.title: Will a quantum computing breakthrough lead to a significant advancement in solving complex natural science problems by 2030?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, a breakthrough in quantum computing results in a significant advancement in solving complex natural science problems, such as those in physics, chemistry, biology, or earth sciences. A "significant advancement" is defined as a solution or substantial progress on a problem that has been widely recognized as unsolved or intractable with classical computing methods. The breakthrough must be documented in a peer-reviewed scientific journal or recognized by a leading scientific organization or consortium. In the absence of a single defining event, a consensus among experts in the field, as reported by at least three reputable news sources (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post), will be considered sufficient evidence. The advancement must be directly attributable to the capabilities of quantum computing, rather than incremental improvements in classical computing or other technologies.

P.title: Will a machine learning model be used to predict significant natural disasters with over 90% accuracy by 2030?
P.body:
This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, a machine learning model is used to predict significant natural disasters (including but not limited to earthquakes, hurricanes, tsunamis, and volcanic eruptions) with over 90% accuracy. 

Significant natural disasters are defined as events causing substantial damage, significant economic loss, or loss of life. The model must predict the location, time frame (within a 48-hour window), and magnitude of the event with over 90% accuracy, verified by subsequent events. 

The prediction model must be recognized and validated by a reputable scientific or governmental organization involved in disaster management or research. 

In the absence of official validation, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post) confirming the use and accuracy of the model are sufficient. 

The model must be operational and used in a real-world scenario, not solely within a research or trial setting.

"Surpass" is defined as achieving a higher accuracy rate, confirmed by at least two independent studies published in peer-reviewed scientific journals or presented at major AI or computer science conferences. 

The studies must compare the performance of machine learning algorithms directly against human performance on identical tasks. The resolution will be based on the consensus of the scientific community or authoritative sources in the field of artificial intelligence and computer science.

P.title: Will the Food and Drug Administration's new policies significantly influence the outcome of the next US presidential election?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by January 1 following the next US presidential election, there is clear evidence that the Food and Drug Administration's (FDA) new policies have significantly influenced the outcome of the presidential election. Significant influence is defined as a measurable impact on voter behavior, election results, or public opinion, directly attributable to the FDA's policies. This impact must be confirmed by at least three reputable sources (e.g., major news organizations like BBC, The New York Times, Washington Post, or academic studies). In the absence of direct evidence, a consensus among political analysts from at least three major news organizations or academic institutions that the FDA's policies played a critical role in the election outcome will also result in a Yes resolution. The resolution will consider only policies introduced before the election year.

P.title: Will a significant legal discovery in astronomy lead to a new international space law by 2030?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, a significant legal discovery in the field of astronomy leads to the establishment of a new international space law. A "significant legal discovery" refers to a finding or development that necessitates the creation or significant amendment of international legal frameworks governing space exploration, use, or security. The new law must be officially adopted by an international governing body recognized for space affairs, such as the United Nations Committee on the Peaceful Uses of Outer Space (COPUOS) or an equivalent entity. The adoption of the law must be documented by official records or announcements from the governing body. In the absence of direct documentation, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post) will be considered sufficient evidence. The law must address the discovery directly and be intended for implementation by member states. This question resolves as YES upon the official adoption of such a law.

Confirmation must come from an official UN announcement or documentation. In the event of a dispute over the novelty of the treaty or agreement, the question will resolve based on the consensus of legal experts in international space law.

P.title: Will France experience a major social movement leading to significant policy changes by 2030?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, France has experienced a major social movement that leads to significant policy changes. A "major social movement" is defined as a widespread mobilization of people across multiple cities, recognized by major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, Le Monde, France24) and involving at least 100,000 participants in total. "Significant policy changes" refer to legislative or executive actions that alter national policy in at least one of the following areas: labor laws, environmental regulations, social welfare, or civil rights. The changes must be directly attributable to the social movement and recognized as such by at least two of the aforementioned news organizations. In the event of multiple movements, the question resolves as Yes if any one of them meets these criteria. Temporary or symbolic measures do not count towards this question's resolution.

P.title: Will a new infectious disease emerge by 2030 that leads to a global pandemic with a mortality rate exceeding that of COVID-19?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, a new infectious disease emerges that leads to a global pandemic with a mortality rate exceeding that of COVID-19 as reported by the World Health Organization (WHO). The mortality rate is defined as the number of confirmed deaths divided by the number of confirmed cases. For the purpose of this question, "global pandemic" is defined as an outbreak of a disease that occurs over a wide geographic area and affects an exceptionally high proportion of the global population. The emergence of the disease must be confirmed by the WHO, and its global impact must be reported by at least three reputable news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post). In the event that the WHO is dissolved or rendered inactive, a consensus of at least three leading health organizations (e.g., CDC, ECDC, China CDC) will be required for resolution. The question will resolve as No if no such disease emerges by the specified date.

P.title: Will a machine learning model be used to predict significant natural disasters with over 90% accuracy by 2030?
P.body:

P.title: Will India become a global leader in quantum computing by 2030?
P.body:
This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, India is recognized as a global leader in the field of quantum computing. Recognition as a global leader requires:
- India hosting at least one quantum computer that ranks among the top 5 in the world for computational power, as reported by a reputable global technology or scientific organization.
- Indian-based researchers or institutions publishing at least 20 significant, peer-reviewed research papers on quantum computing in top-tier scientific journals.
- India successfully commercializing quantum computing technologies, with at least one Indian company being among the top 5 globally in terms of market share or technological innovation in quantum computing.

Recognition must come from authoritative sources in the field of quantum computing, such as the IEEE, the International Quantum Computing Institute, or similar. Reports from major global technology news outlets (e.g., Wired, TechCrunch, Bloomberg Technology) can also contribute to this recognition. In the absence of clear global leadership, the question will resolve as No.

P.title: Will a breakthrough in aerospace engineering lead to a significant improvement in global pandemic response capabilities by 2030?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, a breakthrough in aerospace engineering has led to a significant improvement in global pandemic response capabilities. A "significant improvement" is defined as a development that enables at least a 30% reduction in global pandemic response time or a 20% increase in the distribution efficiency of medical supplies, vaccines, or personnel compared to 2023 standards. The breakthrough must be in the field of aerospace engineering and directly contribute to the improvement of pandemic response capabilities. This includes, but is not limited to, innovations in aircraft design, logistics, and transportation technologies that enhance the speed, efficiency, or reach of pandemic response efforts. The improvement must be documented and recognized by at least one of the following: the World Health Organization (WHO), the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), or a similar authoritative public health body. In the absence of official recognition, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post) are sufficient. Temporary or experimental deployments do not count towards this question's resolution.

P.title: Will a major geopolitical event significantly impact global health security by 2025?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, a major geopolitical event has significantly impacted global health security. The impact on "global health security" must be significant, affecting international health regulations, causing widespread health crises (e.g., pandemics, significant increases in mortality rates, or major disruptions to healthcare systems), or leading to substantial changes in global health policy. The event and its impact on global health security must be confirmed by at least three reputable news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post) or official statements from international health organizations (WHO, CDC). In the absence of direct evidence, a consensus among experts in international relations and global health, as reported by the aforementioned sources, will be considered sufficient. The resolution will consider the direct and immediate effects of the geopolitical event, not long-term consequences that unfold over years.

The agreement must be adopted by a majority of UN member states during a UN Climate Change Conference or a similar high-level meeting. The adoption of the agreement must be confirmed by an official UN announcement or documentation. In the absence of a public announcement, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post) are sufficient. The agreement must represent a new initiative or a significant amendment to existing agreements (e.g., the Paris Agreement) and must be intended for global implementation. Temporary measures or agreements limited to specific regions or groups of countries do not count towards this question's resolution.

Q.title: Will the United Kingdom launch a new national health initiative to combat future pandemics by 2025?
Q.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, the United Kingdom has officially launched a new national health initiative aimed at combating future pandemics. The initiative must be comprehensive, addressing at least prevention, detection, and response strategies for future pandemics. It must be officially announced by the UK government or a relevant health authority. In the absence of a public announcement, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post) are sufficient. The initiative must be new, not an extension or rebranding of existing programs. In the event of a partial launch (e.g., limited to specific regions or aspects of pandemic preparedness), the question will resolve as Yes if the initiative is intended for nationwide application.

reasons: Both questions pertain to significant policy actions by major political entities (the United Nations and the United Kingdom) in response to global challenges (climate change and pandemics).
The adoption of a new global climate agreement by the UN could influence international priorities and funding, potentially affecting the UK's ability to launch new health initiatives.
Global climate agreements often include provisions for public health and resilience, which could be relevant to pandemic preparedness.
The UK's national health initiative could be influenced by international cooperation and funding mechanisms that are part of global climate agreements.
relevance.conclusion: There are plausible reasons to consider the logical combination of these questions, as actions in one area (global climate policy) could have indirect effects on another (national health initiatives).

verification_result.reasoning: In this scenario, P is the proposition that the United Nations will adopt a new global climate agreement before 2030. R is the conditional probability of the United Kingdom launching a new national health initiative to combat future pandemics by 2025, given that the United Nations adopts a new global climate agreement before 2030. S is the conjunction of both events occurring: the United Nations adopting a new global climate agreement before 2030 and the United Kingdom launching a new national health initiative to combat future pandemics by 2025. The conditions for R and S logically follow from the definitions of conditional probability and conjunction, respectively. Therefore, the relationships between P, Q, R, and S are logically consistent and plausible.

P.title: Will significant advancements in climatology lead to a major shift in global climate policy by 2030?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, significant advancements in climatology result in a major shift in global climate policy. A "significant advancement" in climatology is defined as a breakthrough in climate science that leads to a new understanding of climate systems, significantly improves climate models, or provides novel solutions to climate change. A "major shift" in global climate policy is defined as the adoption of new, substantial climate policies or amendments to existing policies by at least three of the following entities: the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC), the European Union, the United States, China, and India. These policies must represent a significant departure from current strategies and aim to substantially reduce greenhouse gas emissions or enhance climate resilience. The shift must be confirmed by official documentation from the relevant entities or credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post, Reuters).

Q_given_P.title: Given significant advancements in climatology lead to a major shift in global climate policy by 2030, will a major breakthrough in genetics lead to a significant increase in crop resilience to climate change by 2030?
Q_given_P.body:
Suppose the following is true: By December 31, 2030, significant advancements in climatology result in a major shift in global climate policy. A "significant advancement" in climatology is defined as a breakthrough in climate science that leads to a new understanding of climate systems, significantly improves climate models, or provides novel solutions to climate change. A "major shift" in global climate policy is defined as the adoption of new, substantial climate policies or amendments to existing policies by at least three of the following entities: the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC), the European Union, the United States, China, and India. These policies must represent a significant departure from current strategies and aim to substantially reduce greenhouse gas emissions or enhance climate resilience. The shift must be confirmed by official documentation from the relevant entities or credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post, Reuters).

Then, will a major breakthrough in genetics lead to a significant increase in crop resilience to climate change by 2030? This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, a major breakthrough in genetics leads to a significant increase in crop resilience to climate change. A "major breakthrough" is defined as a discovery or development that results in a measurable and significant improvement in crop resilience against factors such as drought, temperature extremes, salinity, and pests, compared to the state of the art as of 2023.

The increase in resilience must be demonstrated through peer-reviewed scientific research, recognized by the global scientific community, and must show practical application in at least three different major crops (e.g., rice, wheat, maize).

The breakthrough must be widely recognized by authoritative bodies in the field of agricultural science or genetics, such as the Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) or the International Society for Plant Pathology. In the absence of direct recognition, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post) are sufficient.

In the event of multiple discoveries, the question will resolve as Yes if any one discovery meets the above criteria.

P.title: Will the FIFA World Cup's expansion to 48 teams lead to a significant increase in global soccer viewership by 2030?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, there is a significant increase in global soccer viewership attributed to the FIFA World Cup's expansion to 48 teams. A "significant increase" is defined as a 20% rise in average global viewership numbers for FIFA World Cup events, compared to the average viewership of the three World Cups held prior to the expansion. The assessment of viewership numbers will be based on official FIFA reports or, in their absence, credible data from major sports analytics firms. In the event that FIFA changes the format again before 2030, or if the expansion does not occur, the question will resolve as No. For the purpose of this question, "global soccer viewership" includes both live attendance and television/internet broadcast audiences worldwide.

P.title: Will a biotechnology breakthrough lead to a significant increase in global GDP by 2030?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, a biotechnology breakthrough is directly linked to a significant increase in global GDP. A "significant increase" is defined as a rise in global GDP by at least 5% over a baseline year, adjusted for inflation, attributable to biotechnological advancements. The breakthrough must be widely recognized by the global economic and scientific communities, with confirmation from at least three of the following organizations or publications: The World Bank, International Monetary Fund (IMF), Nature Biotechnology, or Science. The increase in GDP must be reported by reputable global financial news sources, such as Bloomberg, Financial Times, or The Economist. In the event of multiple contributing factors to GDP growth, the biotechnology breakthrough must be identified as the primary driver. This question does not consider incremental improvements in existing biotechnologies but focuses on a novel breakthrough that marks a significant departure from current capabilities.

A "significant increase" is defined as a rise of at least 25% in total funding compared to the year 2020, adjusted for inflation. Climate-related diseases include, but are not limited to, vector-borne diseases, heat-related illnesses, and water-borne diseases. The increase in funding must be confirmed by official reports or statements from major global health organizations such as the World Health Organization (WHO), the United Nations (UN), or the World Bank. In the absence of direct statements, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post) will be considered sufficient. The funding increase must be specifically earmarked for research, prevention, and treatment of climate-related diseases. General increases in health funding without explicit allocation to climate-related diseases do not count towards this question's resolution.

P.title: Will Japan lead the development of a groundbreaking computing technology by 2030?

Q_given_P.title: Conditional on Japan leading the development of a groundbreaking computing technology by 2030, will Germany launch a state-backed digital currency by 2030?
Q_given_P.body:
This question will resolve as Yes if both of the following conditions are met:

1. Japan is recognized as the leading country in the development of a groundbreaking computing technology by December 31, 2030. Groundbreaking computing technology is defined as a technology that represents a significant advancement over existing technologies in terms of performance, efficiency, or capability, and has the potential to transform the computing industry. The leadership in development must be confirmed through:
- Official announcements from a leading Japanese research institution or technology company;
- Coverage by at least three reputable global news organizations (e.g., BBC, The New York Times, The Guardian, Reuters);
- Recognition by a reputable international technology or scientific organization.
In the case of collaborative international projects where Japan plays a leading but not exclusive role, the question will resolve as Yes only if Japan's contribution is widely recognized as pivotal and transformative. Technologies that are only incremental improvements or do not have a clear path to commercialization or practical application by 2030 do not meet the criteria for this question.

2. Germany has officially launched a state-backed digital currency by December 31, 2030. The currency must be recognized as legal tender within Germany and must be backed by the German government or the Bundesbank. The launch of such a currency must be confirmed by an official government announcement or documentation. In the absence of a public announcement, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post) are sufficient. The digital currency must be operational and available for public use, not in a trial phase. In the event of a partial launch (e.g., limited to specific regions or for specific uses), the question will resolve as Yes if the currency is intended for nationwide use. Temporary or pilot programs do not count towards this question's resolution.

If the first condition is not met, this question resolves as N/A.

P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2030, the Supreme Court of the United States adjudicates a landmark legal case involving immunology. The case must directly involve issues related to immunology, such as vaccine mandates, immunotherapy patent disputes, or the legal status of immunological research practices. Resolution will be based on official Supreme Court documents or announcements. In the absence of such documents, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The New York Times, Washington Post, Reuters) will be considered sufficient. Cases that are remanded to lower courts without a substantive ruling on the issues of immunology will not count towards this question's resolution.

P.title: Will France implement a nationwide carbon neutrality policy by 2030?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, France has officially implemented a nationwide policy aimed at achieving carbon neutrality. The policy must encompass measures to significantly reduce greenhouse gas emissions across all sectors of the economy, including but not limited to energy, transportation, agriculture, and industry, with the goal of balancing emitted and absorbed greenhouse gases. Implementation is defined as the policy being enacted into law by the French government, with clear, actionable steps and timelines for achieving carbon neutrality. Confirmation must come from official government announcements or documentation. In the absence of a public announcement, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post) are sufficient. P.title: Will machine learning be used to predict election outcomes in any country with over 90% accuracy before 2030?

P.title: Will the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention publish a comprehensive report on the health impacts of climate change by 2025?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) has published a comprehensive report on the health impacts of climate change. The report must cover a wide range of health impacts directly and indirectly related to climate change, including but not limited to: - Changes in the distribution and prevalence of vector-borne diseases; - Impacts on mental health and well-being; - Effects on air quality and respiratory health; - The influence of extreme weather events on public health. The report must be publicly accessible and recognized by the CDC as comprehensive in its coverage of climate change's health impacts. In the absence of a single comprehensive report, a series of publications by the CDC that collectively cover the criteria above will also satisfy the resolution criteria. P.title: Will a significant international climate change treaty be ratified by 2030?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, a significant international climate change treaty is ratified. A "significant" treaty is defined as one that includes commitments from at least 75% of the world's nations and aims to reduce global greenhouse gas emissions by at least 40% from 1990 levels by 2050. The treaty must be ratified by the participating countries' governments or relevant governing bodies. Ratification is confirmed through official government announcements or documentation. In the absence of a public announcement, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post) are sufficient. The treaty must be new, not an amendment or extension of an existing treaty. In the event of multiple treaties, the question resolves as Yes if at least one meets these criteria.

P.title: Will a new infectious disease outbreak before 2025 lead to a global economic downturn?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2025, a new infectious disease outbreak is identified and leads to a global economic downturn. A "new infectious disease outbreak" refers to the emergence of a disease not previously identified in humans, causing widespread illness. A "global economic downturn" is defined as a decline in global GDP by at least 0.5% over a calendar year, as reported by the International Monetary Fund (IMF) or the World Bank. The outbreak must be confirmed by the World Health Organization (WHO) or the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). In the event of conflicting reports, the question will resolve based on the consensus of these two organizations. The economic impact must be directly attributed to the outbreak by the IMF, the World Bank, or a consensus of economic analysts in reputable financial news sources (e.g., Financial Times, Bloomberg, Reuters).

P.title: Will the United States enter a recession before 2025?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2025, the United States officially enters a recession. A recession is defined as two consecutive quarters of negative GDP growth as reported by the Bureau of Economic Analysis (BEA) of the U.S. Department of Commerce. The determination of a recession by the National Bureau of Economic Research (NBER), which is considered the authoritative body on U.S. recessions, will also result in a Yes resolution. In the absence of an official declaration, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post, Reuters) confirming the recession will be sufficient for resolution. P.title: Will a major breakthrough in pharmacology be announced that significantly extends human lifespan by 2030?
P.body:
This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, a major breakthrough in pharmacology is announced that significantly extends human lifespan. A "major breakthrough" is defined as a pharmacological discovery or development that is scientifically proven to extend the average human lifespan by at least 10 years. The breakthrough must be documented in at least one of the following: 
- A publication in a peer-reviewed scientific journal of high impact. 
- An official announcement from a leading health organization (e.g., World Health Organization, Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, National Institutes of Health). 
For the purpose of this question, "significantly extends human lifespan" refers to the extension of life expectancy at birth. The announcement must be supported by clinical trial results that demonstrate the efficacy of the pharmacological intervention in humans. In the absence of such an announcement, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post) are sufficient. 
In the event of multiple announcements, the question will resolve based on the first announcement that meets these criteria.

Q_given_P.title: Given significant technological influence on the 2024 US presidential election, will the US Congress pass a major law reforming the judicial system before 2030?
Q_given_P.body:
This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2024, there is significant evidence that the development of technology has had a major influence on the outcome of the 2024 US presidential election. Significant influence includes, but is not limited to:
- The use of artificial intelligence in campaign strategies or voter engagement that demonstrably shifts voter preferences or turnout;
- Documented instances of cybersecurity breaches or electronic voting interference that impact the election's integrity or outcome;
- The deployment of new technology platforms or tools that play a pivotal role in shaping public opinion or election results.

Evidence must come from credible sources, such as official government reports, verified data from reputable cybersecurity firms, or coverage by at least three major news organizations (e.g., BBC, The New York Times, The Washington Post). A "major law" is defined as legislation that enacts substantial changes in the structure, powers, or processes of the federal judicial system, including but not limited to the Supreme Court, federal courts of appeal, and district courts. 

Substantial changes may include alterations in the appointment process of judges, changes in the jurisdiction of courts, significant modifications in the procedural rules governing litigation, or the introduction of measures aimed at increasing the transparency or accountability of the judiciary. 

The passage of the law must be confirmed by an official government announcement or documentation. In the absence of a public announcement, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post) are sufficient.

P.title: Will Google announce a significant breakthrough in natural sciences research by 2025?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, Google (or any of its subsidiaries) officially announces a significant breakthrough in the field of natural sciences. The announcement must be made through an official Google press release or a publication in a reputable scientific journal. The breakthrough must be recognized as significant by the scientific community, as evidenced by coverage in at least three major science news outlets (e.g., Scientific American, Nature News, Science Daily) or citations in peer-reviewed scientific journals. In the absence of widespread recognition, the question will resolve as No. The breakthrough must be new, not a continuation or incremental improvement of existing technologies or research.

The discovery must be recognized as significant by the scientific community, evidenced by publication in a peer-reviewed scientific journal, citation in multiple subsequent research works, or acknowledgment by a reputable scientific organization. P.title: Will the ongoing Russo-Ukrainian War lead to a major advancement in military technology by 2024?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2024, a major advancement in military technology directly attributed to the Russo-Ukrainian War is officially announced or recognized. A "major advancement" is defined as a new technology or significant improvement in existing technology that enhances military capabilities in a way that is considered groundbreaking or transformative. This includes, but is not limited to, advancements in weaponry, defense systems, cyber warfare capabilities, or unmanned vehicles. The advancement must be acknowledged by at least one of the following: a defense ministry of a NATO member country, the United Nations, or a reputable defense research institution. In the absence of an official announcement, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post, Reuters) are sufficient. The technology must be deployed or in the process of deployment, not merely in a conceptual or development stage. In the event of multiple advancements, the question will resolve as Yes if at least one meets these criteria.

P.title: Will the US House of Representatives pass a significant economic stimulus package before the end of 2024?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2025, the US House of Representatives passes a significant economic stimulus package. A "significant economic stimulus package" is defined as legislation that allocates at least $500 billion towards economic stimulus measures, including but not limited to tax cuts, direct payments to individuals, unemployment benefits, and funding for state and local governments. The passage of the package must be confirmed by an official announcement from the US House of Representatives or through credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post, Reuters). In the event of multiple packages being passed, the question will resolve as Yes if at least one meets the criteria specified above. Temporary measures or extensions of existing programs do not count towards this question's resolution.

P.title: Will an AI system win a Grand Slam tennis tournament by 2040?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2040, an artificial intelligence (AI) system is officially recognized as the winner of any of the four Grand Slam tennis tournaments (Australian Open, French Open, Wimbledon, or US Open). The AI system must compete under the same conditions as human players and must win the tournament outright. The victory must be acknowledged by the official organizing body of the tournament and reported by at least three reputable news organizations (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post). The AI system is defined as a software system that can make decisions, adapt to playing conditions, and execute physical actions (via a robotic entity) with minimal human intervention. In the event of a team competition where both AI and human players are part of the team, the question will resolve as Yes only if the AI system is the primary contributor to the team's victory. Temporary exhibitions or special categories created specifically for AI or robotic participants do not count towards this question's resolution.

P.title: Will a new vaccine for a major infectious disease be approved by the FDA by 2025?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) has officially approved a new vaccine for a major infectious disease. A "major infectious disease" is defined as a disease that has caused significant morbidity or mortality in the United States or globally within the last 10 years, as reported by the World Health Organization (WHO) or the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). The approval must be for a vaccine that has not been previously available in the United States, and it must be intended for widespread use rather than limited to emergency authorization. The resolution will be based on official FDA announcements or documentation. In the absence of a public announcement, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post) are sufficient. The vaccine must be available for distribution within the United States to count towards this question's resolution.

P.title: Will a new global pandemic treaty be established by the WHO with unanimous support from all member countries by 2025?
P.body:
This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, the World Health Organization (WHO) has established a new global pandemic treaty that has received unanimous support from all member countries. 

For the purposes of this question, a "global pandemic treaty" refers to a formal, legally binding agreement between WHO member countries aimed at preventing, preparing for, and responding to future pandemics. Unanimous support means that all member countries of the WHO at the time of the treaty's establishment have formally agreed to the treaty's terms without exception. 

Confirmation must come from an official WHO announcement or documentation. In the absence of an official announcement, confirmation from at least three reputable news organizations (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post) will be considered sufficient. 

In the event that the WHO gains new members after the establishment of the treaty but before the resolution date, the treaty must have been agreed upon by all members present at the time of establishment for this question to resolve as Yes.
